snippet.textDisplay:
Samsung, the Pentile-Display, Diamond-Pixel Display Garbage? Repeated patent thieves from IPS to TSMC fabrication?

LG is better. TSMC is better. Snapdragon is better.
If only Steve Jobs passed away a little later, then RGBY joint project with Sharp would have been standard. Not only independent Primary Colours but Secondary Colours as well which was to be succeeded with RGBYW so that brightness doesn't have to multiply for showing White by the number of Pixel Combination (RGB= x3 for White) and achieve Uniform brightness. It's 2020, and it's still a Sunburn with white-backgrounds in midnight.
snippet.textOriginal:
Samsung, the Pentile-Display, Diamond-Pixel Display Garbage? Repeated patent thieves from IPS to TSMC fabrication?

LG is better. TSMC is better. Snapdragon is better.
If only Steve Jobs passed away a little later, then RGBY joint project with Sharp would have been standard. Not only independent Primary Colours but Secondary Colours as well which was to be succeeded with RGBYW so that brightness doesn't have to multiply for showing White by the number of Pixel Combination (RGB= x3 for White) and achieve Uniform brightness. It's 2020, and it's still a Sunburn with white-backgrounds in midnight.

snippet.textDisplay:
In the end, it doesn't matter anyway because nobody needs 8K.
As long as you don't have eyes like a falcon and are not sitting way to close in front of a giant TV then you just won't see the difference between a 4K and 8K TV.
If they want to make high-res panels they should focus on VR devices. There they still have some headroom to make the resolution better.

snippet.textDisplay:
If we need microscopes to actually discern whats 8K or not, that alone should wake us all up to just how ridiculous and absurd this race for higher resolution has become. The sad fact is that more than 6 feet away on a standard 50 inch display no one can even tell the difference of anything above 1080p anymore. This is all a joke and proof we live in a pathetic world where hype, gimmicks and marketing trump the total lack of actual ideas.Of course, nothing trumps 4K 5 inch screens like on Sony phones (that no one buys by the way), soon to be 8K too I'm sure.. and good luck finding a microscope to inspect those pixels and making sure they are all there.

Damn I can't wait for 16K.. sorry, I mean 32..

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm sure both companies would argue their technology is superior than a rival, because each might have features that do a better job in some areas, whilst failing in others. However, I've always found most reviewers do whar the can to test multiple products, for effective comparison.

Regardless of who considers their TV to have "real" 8K, we should consider witholding judgment until reviewers have had their opportunity.

snippet.textDisplay: But how could contrast ratio be good and the contrast modulation be bad looking at the equation Cm= (Lw-Lk)/(Lw+Lk) ? If contrast ratio is good then by that equation Cm will naturally be very good.
snippet.textOriginal: But how could contrast ratio be good and the contrast modulation be bad looking at the equation Cm= (Lw-Lk)/(Lw+Lk) ? If contrast ratio is good then by that equation Cm will naturally be very good.

snippet.textDisplay:
"Real" 8K is 8640*4320.
But because nobody wants to have a ratio of 2:1 on the screen, manufactureres invented "UHD".
So for clarifying that issue: UHD is correct.
If you however use 4K or 8K, 16K and so on, for that being true, you either have to have a contrast ratio of 2:1 or 20:10, or - you use the term "8K in a contrast ratio of 16:10 or 21:10 or whatever".
It's important that you clarify, which contrast ratio you are using.
The number in front of the "K" is just an assumption of the number of pixels - multiplied by a thousand - k stands for kilo, like in "kilogramm" which assumes a thousand gramm.
But because "Pixels" are expensive and nobody wants to have an aspect ratio of 2:1, as I said before, look at the second sentence.
I however like numbers more than words, and so I like the term 8K-UHD more than SuperUHD or 8K - if just 8K is wrongly used for 7680*4320.
But if 8K is used correctly in a term like "8K by 16:10" it's great.

Why?
Reason 1: If promoted just with 8K, it would be a wrong assumption of the screen having an aspect ratio of 2:1, which mostly isn't true.
So they have to promote it like: 8K 16:10 or 8K 21:10 or anything along those lines.


Reason 2: If they would use the words, it might be going as follows (in the future):
SD (anything below 720p), HD (720p), FullHD (1080p), UltraHD (3840*2160), Super UltraHD (7680*4320), and then?
It would maybe be: Super Dupa UltraHD(for around 16K), Mega Super Dupa UltraHD(for around 32K), Ultra Mega Super Dupa UltraHD(for around 64K), and so on.


Did you get that?


We might have to remember massive names to compare between resolutions.
Does that make sense?


The numeric terms would just be small and understandable.


I could give you the next terms and their resolutions easily.
It would be like this:


720p HD,
1080p or FullHD, 1920*1080

2K 2160*1080
4K 4320*2160
8K 8640*4320
16K 17280*8640
32K 34560*17280
64K 69120*34560
128K 138240*69120
256K 276480*138240
512K 552960*276480
1024K or 1M 1105920*552960 ........=1080*2^10
2M 2211840*1105920
4M
...
1024M or 1G = 1080*2^20 = 1 132 462 080*566 231 040 = 641 235 181 318 963 200 pixels


Did you get that?
Same as today's numbers on the computer RAM.
Easy, right?


I'm just curious and I'd like to ask you (maybe you are in the development of new names for new resolutions on screens):


Which names would you for yourself create for those screen resolutions above?
And what thoughts do you have about it?



Please write that in the comments.
Thanks
snippet.textOriginal:

But because nobody wants to have a ratio of 2:1 on the screen, manufactureres invented "UHD".
So for clarifying that issue: UHD is correct.
If you however use 4K or 8K, 16K and so on, for that being true, you either have to have a contrast ratio of 2:1 or 20:10, or - you use the term "8K in a contrast ratio of 16:10 or 21:10 or whatever".
It's important that you clarify, which contrast ratio you are using.
The number in front of the "K" is just an assumption of the number of pixels - multiplied by a thousand - k stands for kilo, like in "kilogramm" which assumes a thousand gramm.
But because "Pixels" are expensive and nobody wants to have an aspect ratio of 2:1, as I said before, look at the second sentence.
I however like numbers more than words, and so I like the term 8K-UHD more than SuperUHD or 8K - if just 8K is wrongly used for 7680*4320.
But if 8K is used correctly in a term like "8K by 16:10" it's great. 

Why?
Reason 1: If promoted just with 8K, it would be a wrong assumption of the screen having an aspect ratio of 2:1, which mostly isn't true.
So they have to promote it like: 8K 16:10 or 8K 21:10 or anything along those lines.


Reason 2: If they would use the words, it might be going as follows (in the future):
SD (anything below 720p), HD (720p), FullHD (1080p), UltraHD (3840*2160), Super UltraHD (7680*4320), and then?
It would maybe be: Super Dupa UltraHD(for around 16K), Mega Super Dupa UltraHD(for around 32K), Ultra Mega Super Dupa UltraHD(for around 64K), and so on.


Did you get that?


We might have to remember massive names to compare between resolutions.
Does that make sense?


The numeric terms would just be small and understandable.


I could give you the next terms and their resolutions easily.
It would be like this:


720p HD,
 1080p or FullHD, 1920*1080

 2K  2160*1080
4K 4320*2160
8K 8640*4320
16K 17280*8640
32K 34560*17280
64K 69120*34560
128K 138240*69120
256K 276480*138240
512K 552960*276480
1024K or 1M  1105920*552960 ........=1080*2^10
2M 2211840*1105920
4M
...
1024M or 1G = 1080*2^20 = 1 132 462 080*566 231 040 = 641 235 181 318 963 200 pixels 


Did you get that?
Same as today's numbers on the computer RAM.
Easy, right?


I'm just curious and I'd like to ask you (maybe you are in the development of new names for new resolutions on screens):


Which names would you  for yourself create for those screen resolutions above?
And what thoughts do you have about it?



Please write that in the comments.
Thanks

snippet.textDisplay:
I recognized the LG Real thing. The Real comes from their own tech branding. Like their beamer CineBeam LED Real 4K UHD. And LG's "Real Cinema" technology in their TV's image processing chip (α9/XD Engine).
It's designed to smoothy play 24Hz content (cinema).
You can access it in the "Picture Mode Settings" menu.
snippet.textOriginal:
I recognized the LG Real thing. The *Real* comes from their own tech branding. Like their beamer CineBeam LED *Real* 4K UHD. And LG's "Real Cinema" technology in their TV's image processing chip (α9/XD Engine).
It's designed to smoothy play 24Hz content (cinema).
You can access it in the "Picture Mode Settings" menu.

snippet.textDisplay:
Pointless. There's less than a handful of cameras that shoot 8K and there are no 8K movies even released. The only reason productions shoot in 8K is for better motion tracking for visual effects. They'll always downscale to at least 4K for release.

Consumer demand is causing this. 4K is far more than enough and the demand is creating a standard faster than hollywood or even game designers will be able to keep up. The processing speed you'd need to design an 8K game and it would probably end up being terabytes in size.

If you buy into this nonsense you're wasting your money. 8K TVs will be a quarter the price by the time they start releasing an acceptable amount of 8K content.
snippet.textOriginal:
Pointless. There's less than a handful of cameras that shoot 8K and there are no 8K movies even released. The only reason productions shoot in 8K is for better motion tracking for visual effects. They'll always downscale to at least 4K for release.

Consumer demand is causing this. 4K is far more than enough and the demand is creating a standard faster than hollywood or even game designers will be able to keep up. The processing speed you'd need to design an 8K game and it would probably end up being terabytes in size.

If you buy into this nonsense you're wasting your money. 8K TVs will be a quarter the price by the time they start releasing an acceptable amount of 8K content.

snippet.textDisplay:
As long as the TV has 33,177,600 pixels, it's a true 8K TV. It doesn't matter how you dither the light from the pixels or if you keep 25% of the pixels displaying only white. So long as the panel has all the pixels, that's what determines the resolution of the panel. Now if 25% of those pixels were not emitting light, that's a different story. But just because a TV has a certain amount of pixels, doesn't mean a manufacturer can't manipulate them in certain ways.

But again it was a first generation panel that was on sale for only a year. And now Samsung's 8K displays are just like any other 8K screen from any other manufacturer. First generation products often have band aid technology to make something work just to get it to market, as enginers figure out the final solution. This often happens so the manufacturer can claim first to market, or because they know only first adopters will be interested anyways. They know that 99.9% of the average joe's out there won't buy it anyway first year out.

Also I have news for ya! ^_~ Much of your 4K content out there isn't actualy native 4K. Many shows and hollywood movies are actualy rendered in 2K resolutions to this day. Even if they were shot with 4K and 8K cameras. This is because when they go to editing, it's far easier to work and process 2K resolutions. Especially when adding special effects. So major films like some of the Transformer movies for example, are actualy 2K. The studios then upconvert the move to 4K for Netflix or Blu-Ray release. (Granted their upconversion process is better than what your high end TV can do when upconverting lower resolution videos.) So you're actualy buying very well done upconverted 2K movies in reality. But it's still not as good as native 4K.

So I wouldn't worry about 8K. Your likely never going to see "real" 8K for a very, very, long time. Half the time your not even seeing "real" 4K even from hollywood films. It's a 50/50 toss up if it was edited entirely in 4K.
snippet.textOriginal:

So long as the panel has all the pixels, that's what determines the resolution of the panel. Now if 25% of those pixels were not emitting light, that's a different story. But just because a TV has a certain amount of pixels, doesn't mean a manufacturer can't manipulate them in certain ways. 

But again it was a first generation panel that was on sale for only a year. And now Samsung's 8K displays are just like any other 8K screen from any other manufacturer. First generation products often have band aid technology to make something work just to get it to market, as enginers figure out the final solution. This often happens so the manufacturer can claim first to market, or because they know only first adopters will be interested anyways. They know that 99.9% of the average joe's out there won't buy it anyway first year out. 

Also I have news for ya! ^_~  Much of your 4K content out there isn't actualy native 4K. Many shows and hollywood movies are actualy rendered in 2K resolutions to this day. Even if they were shot with 4K and 8K cameras. This is because when they go to editing, it's far easier to work and process 2K resolutions. Especially when adding special effects. So major films like some of the Transformer movies for example, are actualy 2K. The studios then upconvert the move to 4K for Netflix or Blu-Ray release. (Granted their upconversion process is better than what your high end TV can do when upconverting lower resolution videos.) So you're actualy buying very well done upconverted 2K movies in reality. But it's still not as good as native 4K. 

So I wouldn't worry about 8K. Your likely never going to see "real" 8K for a very, very, long time.  Half the time your not even seeing "real" 4K even from hollywood films. It's a 50/50 toss up if it was edited entirely in 4K.

snippet.textDisplay: He fails to inform viewers that the lg nano is about 2x the price of the q900r. Many people are probably aware of the fact that the q900r has poor contrast modulation, but you also have to realize that the 2019 q900r had a Massive drop in price and still has great picture quality. For the price, at about $2500 vs $5000, I'd pick samsung for first gen. There is very little reason to upgrade now, but if you do, it's best to compromise a little. By the time 8k is the better standard for cable and movie viewing there may have been many improvements to the 8k lines of both lg and samsung and it's best to skip first gen or save while you can  to prepare for something bettter.
snippet.textOriginal: He fails to inform viewers that the lg nano is about 2x the price of the q900r. Many people are probably aware of the fact that the q900r has poor contrast modulation, but you also have to realize that the 2019 q900r had a Massive drop in price and still has great picture quality. For the price, at about $2500 vs $5000, I'd pick samsung for first gen. There is very little reason to upgrade now, but if you do, it's best to compromise a little. By the time 8k is the better standard for cable and movie viewing there may have been many improvements to the 8k lines of both lg and samsung and it's best to skip first gen or save while you can  to prepare for something bettter.

snippet.textOriginal: Ironic given that LG is the company that was selling bogus 4k TVs that had only 3k pixels and then a white sub-pixel for brightness.

snippet.textDisplay: LG to me will always carry the reminder of its history of being 'Goldstar' in the 1980's and 90's then re-branded to 'Lucky Goldstar' (LG) yes that is what LG really did officially stand for in the 1990s!!!  then ''so called'' re-branded yet again to 'Lifes Good' ... Either way, its always been a bottom of the range budget brand like Goodmans and other Walmart specials... Their vcr's were cheap crap, their cd and dvd players were always cheap crap, their hi-fi's were cheap crap, and guess what? so were their tv's right upto 2010 when I left the trade!
snippet.textOriginal: LG to me will always carry the reminder of its history of being 'Goldstar' in the 1980's and 90's then re-branded to 'Lucky Goldstar' (LG) yes that is what LG really did officially stand for in the 1990s!!!  then ''so called'' re-branded yet again to 'Lifes Good' ... Their vcr's were cheap crap, their cd and dvd players were always cheap crap, their hi-fi's were cheap crap, and guess what? so were their tv's right upto 2010 when I left the trade!
